videos.title: The Tale of Peter Rabbit - Fairy Tales - Kids Stories - by Beatrix Potter
videos.description:
A faithful telling of "The Tale of Peter Rabbit," by Beatrix Potter. This funny story is all about a naughty bunny who should really listen to his mother. Makes a perfect bedtime story. 
This is the most well-known of Beatrix Potter's short books for children. But she wrote many more stories!  

Here's a playlist of more of her charming tales, including Miss Moppet, Jemima Puddle-Duck, Tom Kitten,  and Squirrel Nutkin:
https://youtu.be/-n-VdURmHBs

❤❤❤❤❤
Raising kids who love to read?
We recommend Little Fun Club - delivers adventurous books to your door every month!
https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=716163&u=1564522&m=58679&urllink=&afftrack=

❤❤❤❤❤
All illustrations are from Project Gutenberg.

❤❤❤❤❤
Do your kids love science and nature? Learning about animals is a great way to keep kids excited about their natural world. Perfect for kids in school or homeschoolers!  

Be sure to SUBSCRIBE so you don’t miss our next episode!
http://bit.ly/1MJY7Cd

❤❤❤❤❤

National Geographic Little Kids First Big Book of Animals
http://amzn.to/2sb4d6L

National Geographic Cutest Animals Sticker Activity Book: Over 1000 Stickers!
http://amzn.to/2u8y6q1

And these are great for Bigger Kids:

National Geographic Animal Encyclopedia: 2500 Animals with Photos, Maps, and More!
http://amzn.to/2swBuJ8

http://amzn.to/2tvOO4x

Find more great resources on Amazon Free Time Unlimited
Unlimited access to 13,000 kid-friendly books, movies, TV shows, educational apps, and games.
http://amzn.to/2DGtlJ6

Director: Michael Harrison
Producer: Kimberly Hatch Harrison

videos.title: Bedtime Stories: The Tale of Squirrel Nutkin, a story by Beatrix Potter
videos.description:
Do you love watching squirrels gather nuts in the fall?  Here's a fun story about a sassy squirrel from Beatrix Potter (author of Peter Rabbit).  

This is a faithful telling of "The Tale of Squirrel Nutkin," by Beatrix Potter, using her exact words and her beautiful original watercolour illustrations. Makes a perfect bedtime story!
❤❤❤❤❤
Raising kids who love to read?
We recommend Little Fun Club - delivers adventurous books to your door every month!
https://shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=716163&u=1564522&m=58679&urllink=&afftrack=

❤❤❤❤❤
♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
If you liked this story, don't miss these other wonderful stories from Beatrix Potter!

The Tale of Peter Rabbit  http://bit.ly/2w7mFiF
The Story of Miss Moppet  http://bit.ly/2hhxZGF
The Tale of Benjamin Bunny  http://bit.ly/2xnGKEq
The Tale of Jemima Puddleduck  http://bit.ly/2fjZCOJ

Reading stories out loud is a great way to help kids learn to read.  It helps them pay attention, and learn to understand the basic rules of writing and composition. Don't miss this chance to help your kids develop a love for reading - read to them every day if you can! 

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

videos.title: Why do we have Seasons? Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter - Science for Kids
videos.description:
There are four seasons: Spring, Summer, Fall (also known as Autumn), and Winter.  Learn about what causes the different seasons, and what's special about each one.

videos.title: Welcome to Arithmetic! Learn all the basics with us.
videos.description:
We're going to Math Camp!  We're learning about ARITHMETIC.  We'll learn how to add, subtract, multiply, and divide.  We'll also learn about whole numbers (integers), fractions, decimals, and complex numbers. These are topics that first come up in arithmetic, but will continue to be helpful in other math subjects like algebra, trigonometry, geometry, and more.  So get yer paper and pencils and join us for a fun-filled outdoor adventure (sunscreen optional).

videos.title: Arithmetic: Commutative Property of Addition
videos.description:
The Commutative Property of Addition means it doesn't matter which order you add two numbers.  5 + 3 = 8, and 3 + 5 = 8.

videos.title: Arithmetic: Associative Property of Addition
videos.description:
The Associative Property of Addition comes up when you add three or more numbers together.  Because of this property, you can add any two of the numbers together at a time:  (2 + 3) + 5 = 2 + (3 + 5). You get the same answer no matter which two numbers you add first.

videos.title: Arithmetic: What is zero? (Kids)
videos.description:
Zero is one of the most useful numbers of all. It's how we say we have no objects. If you start with 4 marshmallows, and give all 4 of them away, you have ZERO marshmallows left!  We need to use zero when we add and subtract.  Zero also does interesting things when you multiply it by any number.  You get zero, every time. Zero wins!

videos.title: Arithmetic: What are Integers (aka Whole Numbers, Counting Numbers, Natural Numbers)
videos.description:
We call them whole numbers, counting numbers, natural numbers...but the mathy-math name is integers.  This includes the numbers you use to count things:
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and so on...
And the absence of things:
-1, -2, -3, -4, -5, -6, and so on...
And don't forget the number 0 (zero) to say we have exactly NO things. 

To learn more about the number zero, watch this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EQUUa74b2Fw

In this video, we learn how to multiply two numbers, and how it's okay to multiply them in either direction because of the Commutative Property of Multiplication.  We also learn about how multiplying by 1 doesn't change a number.

videos.description:
Remember - multiplication is repeated addition.  And since it doesn't matter what order you add things, that means it doesn't matter what order you multiply things!  This is the Commutative Property of Multiplication.  Think of the word commute!

videos.title: Arithmetic: Multiplication Symbols
videos.description:
How do you show you are multiplying two numbers?  We have two symbols commonly used:  a "x" and a "·"  Careful, that second one isn't a period, although it looks like one!  It should be written higher up, in the middle of a line, not down at the bottom like a period.  
Ask your teacher which symbol you should use in your math class.  

Did you know there's even a THIRD way to write multiplication?  It's not so much a symbol, but...you can enclose numbers in parentheses and that means multiplication, too.  Like this:  (3)(5) means...3x5!  

About this series:
Every Thursday, we're going to Math Camp!  This year, we're learning about ARITHMETIC.  We'll learn how to add, subtract, multiply, and divide. videos.title: Arithmetic: What is the symbol for Integers?
videos.description:
In your math book, you might see this symbol used: ℤ
What is that!!??  It's the symbol for integers (also known as whole numbers).  It's a "Blackboard Z" - sometimes written as a bold Z.  Why the letter Z?  It comes from the German word for number, "zahlen."

videos.title: Arithmetic: What are Identity Elements?
videos.description:
What's an Identity Element?  It lets a number keep its identity!  For example:  0 is the identity element for addition, because if you add it to any number, the number doesn't change.  1 is the identity element for multiplication, because if you multiply any number by 1, the number doesn't change.  Careful!  Identity elements are specific to each operation (addition, multiplication, etc.).  So while 1 is the identity element for multiplication, it is NOT the identity element for addition.

About this series:
Every Thursday, we're going to Math Camp!  This year, we're learning about ARITHMETIC.  We'll learn how to add, subtract, multiply, and divide.  We'll also learn about whole numbers (integers), fractions, decimals, and complex numbers. videos.title: Arithmetic: What is a Divisor (or a Factor)?
videos.description:
A divisor (or a factor) evenly divides a number, leaving no remainder.  So for example, 2 is a divisor of 10, because it evenly divides 10 (you get a quotient of 5), leaving no remainder. 3 is not a factor of 10, because you get a quotient of 3 and a remainder of 1.

videos.title: Arithmetic: More Practice with Division
videos.description:
Division is all about sharing and fairness.  When you divide something, you’re giving equal amounts to different people.  Sometimes everything works out perfectly and there’s nothing leftover.  Other times you can’t divide things equally and there will be leftovers. We call the leftovers in division the "remainder."

videos.title: Arithmetic: Multiply before Adding
videos.description:
We've learned about the Associative Properties for Addition and Multiplication. They say you can add 3 or more numbers in any order, and you can multiply 3 or more numbers in any order.  But what happens if you need to add AND multiply?  Like in 2 + 3 x 5?  It turns out, there's a rule you always follow:  Multiply Before You Add.  

About this series:
Every Thursday, we're going to Math Camp!  This year, we're learning about ARITHMETIC.  We'll learn how to add, subtract, multiply, and divide.  We'll also learn about whole numbers (integers), fractions, decimals, and complex numbers. These are topics that first come up in arithmetic, but will continue to be helpful in other math subjects like algebra, trigonometry, geometry, and more. videos.title: Arithmetic: How do you use Parentheses?
videos.description:
We've learned the important lesson that you multiply before you add.  So if you see 2 + 4 x 3, you get 2 + 12 = 14.  But how would you write it if you WANT someone to add first?  You use PARENTHESES!  These: ( ) are parentheses, and the rule is you do everything inside the parentheses first.  So (2 + 4) x 3 = (8) x 3 = 24.

videos.title: How to Mix 3 Colors to Make a Rainbow - Science Experiments for Kids - Primary Colors
videos.description:
How to Mix 3 Colors to Make a Rainbow - Science Experiments for Kids - Primary Colors

Do you know how to MAKE A RAINBOW?  Join Professor Labcoat as he makes the entire rainbow from just 3 colors - red, yellow, and blue. 

red + blue makes purple
yellow + blue makes green
red + yellow makes orange

Learn about primary colors, secondary colors, and tertiary colors.
We also show you a great memory aid for remembering all the colors of the rainbow! 

Make sure to WATCH TO THE END for outtakes! 

It's never too early to get kids excited about science by doing demonstrations and experiments.Hands-on experience with color mixing for kids is a great way to remember these concepts for good.  Let us know what other videos you'd like to see in the comments below! 

Don't forget to subscribe:
http://bit.ly/1MJY7Cd

And share our channel with your friends! That will help us grow! 
Thank you for watching. :)


MATERIALS USED SO YOU CAN DO THIS AT HOME:
- 7 cups
-  water
-  milk
-  red, yellow, and blue food coloring drops

videos.title: Vinegar + Baking Soda + Balloons = FIZZY FUN! | Kids Science Experiments | Science for Kids
videos.description:
Tweet about this video! http://bit.ly/1ZUlufx
#socraticakids #socraticakidsscience

Vinegar + Baking Soda + Balloons = FIZZY FUN! | Kids Science Experiments | Science for Kids

********
What happens when you add vinegar to baking soda?  
Join Professor Labcoat on his latest science demonstration. He'll show you how fizzy and fun these simple household items can be.  They can even be used to blow up balloons!
Make sure to WATCH TO THE END for outtakes! 

It's never too early to get kids excited about science by doing demonstrations and experiments. Let us know what other videos you'd like to see in the comments below! 

Our kids' science playlist: http://bit.ly/23wSeOZ
Don't forget to subscribe!  http://bit.ly/1MJY7Cd
Twitter!  

And share our channel with your friends! That will help us grow! 
Thank you for watching. :)

********
MATERIALS USED SO YOU CAN DO THIS AT HOME:

- vinegar
- baking soda
- mixing dish
- bottle
- balloons (try several of different sizes)
- 2 funnels
- tablespoon

If you're interested in the chemical reaction that is taking place, it's the combination of vinegar (acetic acid) and baking soda (also known as sodium bicarbonate). The gas released is Carbon Dioxide. You write the chemical reaction like this:

HC2H3O2 + NaHCO3 → NaC2H3O2 + H2O + CO2 
(the numbers should all be subscripts)

videos.description:
The Wheels on the Bus song is one of the all-time best English Songs for Kids! Kindergarten and preschool kids LOVE to sing along. Our version is a NEW TWIST on this old favorite kids song - because our bus can take us anywhere! 

Join Bus Driver Tony as our Wheels on the Bus video takes you on an Adventure Around the World!  Our Magic Bus visits New York; London, England; Paris, France; The North Pole; the Outback in Australia; a grassland safari in Africa; the Great Wall of China; and the South Pole (Antarctica).  Can you guess who we’ll meet in each place?  Lyrics to this fun adventure are found below.  Sing Along with Us! 

Nursery rhymes and nursery songs are a great way to develop kids’ memories.  Kids music is an important part of their education, starting when they are babies! They learn rhythm, how to sing along with a basic melody, and develop their memorization skills by learning lyrics. Singing along with kids songs isn’t just fun - it’s a great brain workout!

videos.title: 📖 52 Kindergarten Sight Words - How to Read - Dolch sightwords 📖
videos.description:
📖 When you learn to read, you need to recognize some words on sight.  These are called "sight words."  In the Dolch system, there are 52 words at the Kindergarten level that beginning readers need to learn. 

This video has all 52 Kindergarten Sight Words, with each word spelled and pronounced, and used in a sentence. The pictures will help beginning readers remember each word.  

It's also a great idea to learn sight words if you are new to English! 

40 Preschool Sight Words: http://bit.ly/29CR557

If you found this video helpful, please like it and share it with your friends!

videos.title: Dinosaurs for Kids – Fossils for Kids – Stegosaurus
videos.description:
It’s the SUPER FUN Puppet Science Spectacular Show! 
This is our very first episode! And our special guest is...STEGOSAURUS!!!

Stegosaurus is VERY BIG...and so is this first episode!
Hosts: Kromp (a monster), Leonard (a frog), Dr. Fox (a fox), and more!
You’ll learn about DINOSAURS and the comparison BIGGER and SMALLER.

videos.title: DIY Slime for Kids – How to Make Slime  (Oobleck) – Science Experiments to do at Home
videos.description:
How to Make Slime is one of the segments from our Brand New Puppet Science Show!  This segment is a SNEAK PEEK at our upcoming episode all about SLIME!! 

In this segment, Charlie makes a beautiful, shiny PURPLE slime!  This slime is also called an OOBLECK. Making slime is a fun and easy science experiment for kids.

You can follow along at home! Here are the supplies you'll need for this science project:

1/2 cup water
1/2 cup glue
1/2 cup liquid starch
glitter and food colouring
2 bowls
a spoon

You can find these supplies here:

White glue
http://amzn.to/2mthZTN

Liquid starch
http://amzn.to/2nnvHqa

Food coloring
http://amzn.to/2nnAgku

Glitter
http://amzn.to/2mUI0aN

❤❤❤❤❤
What do you know about Oobleck? Have you ever touched it? It has some VERY strange behavior.  Sometimes it acts like a liquid, and sometimes it acts like a solid! After you make your slime, notice how it behaves like a thick liquid if you squeeze it slowly, but it seems more like a solid if you slap it with your hand.

Puppet Science is a great way for kids to get involved in science. They can play along with their puppet friends and learn a lot! Charlie's Lab lets kids do hands-on activities that are fun and safe, with step-by-step instructions. This is perfect if you are looking for experience following directions, and for sensory play. This is a great science activity for kids in preschool, kindergarten and grade school.

videos.description:
SLIME (Oobleck) is so fun for Preschool and Kindergarten Kids! We’ll make sparkly purple slime with help from our puppet friends. Special guests: a snail and an oyster teach kids more about mucus and other slimy things! 

Oobleck is a very strange and interesting substance. If you pour it, it acts like a liquid, but if you squeeze it or hit it, it acts like a solid! We call it a “Non-Newtonian Fluid.” Make it yourself and see! 

Do your kids love science? Puppet science is a great way to keep kids excited about science and do safe and educational science activities!  Perfect for preschool, kindergarten, and homeschool activities.

videos.title: What are Magnets for Kids  ||  Educational Toys for Kids  ||  Kids Science
videos.description:
Magnets are so much fun to play with! Did you know magnets are a special kind of metal? Our puppet friends Topher and Leonard play with magnets and learn about how they work. They also learn the names of shapes, including triangles, squares, hexagons, pyramids, and tetrahedrons! 

Welcome to Topher's Toybox, where we unbox and play with Educational Toys for Kids! Today Topher and his friend Leonard review a set of Magnetic Building Blocks from 4DBlocks - Play it , Love it!
You can get your own set here:
Special Promotion:  Summer Sale! 30% off Magnetic Blocks featured in our video!  
CODE: PROMO4DB https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01HXYXKMU

❤❤❤❤❤
Topher and Leonard talk about how magnets are a special kind of metal that pulls on other metals! They use triangles and squares to build all kinds of shapes, including a cube, a house, a car, and two kinds of pyramids (a traditional pyramid like the Egyptians used, and a tetrahedron, also known as a triangular pyramid). 

Playing with educational toys is such a fun way for kids to learn about math and science.  Playing with puppets is even more fun!  Perfect for  early education whether your kids are in preschool, kindergarten, or you're homeschooling. We're looking for other educational toys to feature on Topher's Toybox, so please let us know other ways your kids love learning through play in the comments!

Be sure to Subscribe to Socratica Kids!
http://bit.ly/1MJY7Cd

videos.title: Stars & Constellations for Kids  ||  Science for Kids || Educational Toys
videos.description:
Do your kids want to know - What are Stars & Constellations?
We start outside, looking at the stars, then head inside & play!
Welcome to Topher's Toybox, where we unbox and play with Educational Toys for kids! Today Topher and his friend Leonard unbox a set of Glow in the Dark Stars - “Glow Stars Supernova” from Addie and Emmas! 
You can get your own set here!
http://amzn.to/2vJwdEq

Topher and Leonard talk about how stars are very big, very hot, and very far away. They also talk about how our Sun is a star!  Then they play with making constellations.  We'll see constellations like the Big Dipper, Orion, and Cassiopeia! 

*BONUS* BIG Vocabulary word: Phosphorescence! 

GOOF ALERT: at 1:50 we said the Sun was 93 million miles away (correct) but then said that was 150 kilometers. We should have said 150 MILLION kilometers!! 

❤❤❤❤❤

videos.title: The Moon for Kids || Moon Phases for Kids || Astronomy for Kids
videos.description:
What do you know about the moon? How big is it? Can we live there?  Today Kromp and Leonard meet our Moon and ask him a few questions. We learn about the Moon Phases and more! Learn about outer space with your puppet friends! 

Did you know we’ve actually visited the moon?  The first two men who walked on the moon were named Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin. That was back in 1969.  A total of 12 people have walked on the moon!  Would you like to go? 

You have to wear a spacesuit when you’re there, because there’s no air. It also gets super hot during the day, and super hot at night.  Maybe NASA will let you borrow one of their spacesuits! 

Fun Moon Phases Activity:  Kids can go outside at night (bring a grownup!) and draw how much of the moon they see.  In about 4 weeks, they’ll have drawings for all the phases of the moon!

videos.title: 10 Arctic Animals for Kids – Snow Animals for Kids – Polar Animals
videos.description:
This video is for Kids who LOVE animals! Which Animals live in the Arctic? Meet 10 of the most interesting animals we’ve ever seen! Learn important facts about each of these beautiful North Pole Animals who like to live where it’s VERY chilly!

These animals all live in the Arctic, a very cold region close to the North Pole. The Arctic Ocean has the lowest salt content of any of the oceans. It's also the smallest ocean! But it's home to many fascinating animals. 

We just made a longer video all about POLAR BEARS!
http://bit.ly/PolarBears4Kids

Here you can skip to each Arctic Animal:
0:10  Polar Bear - the largest bear in the world
0:51  Sea Otter - the animal with the densest fur
1:25  Ermine - white weasels
1:52  Harp Seal - excellent swimmers and divers
2:22  Narwhal - whale with a very, very long tooth
3:02  Arctic Wolf - looks like a large dog with small ears
3:37  Puffin - live on cliffs and dive into the ocean to hunt
4:06  Wolverine - aggressive little weasel
4:34  Walrus - have long tusks and mustaches
5:16  Orca - aka “Killer Whales” 

Which Arctic Animal did you like best? 
Is there another animal you’d like to learn about?

videos.title: Spiders for Kids  || Animals for Kids || Science for Kids
videos.description:
Did you know spiders are NOT insects? Insects have 6 legs. Spiders have 8! Spiders actually like to EAT insects. Most spiders make webs using silk they make themselves. And they don’t have to go to school to learn how - they are born knowing all about how to build webs and catch insects to eat. 

Some people are VERY afraid of spiders. We call this ARACHNOPHOBIA. But don’t worry - Itsy Bitsy is a very nice spider. Come say hello! 

SPIDER ACTIVITY IDEA:  You can make a spider out of pipe cleaners!  Remember to give your spider 8 fuzzy legs. 
Pipe Cleaners
http://amzn.to/2h3wgko

Itsy Bitsy Spider Song: http://bit.ly/ItsyBitsySong

videos.title: Octopus for Kids  || Ocean Animals for Kids
videos.description:
Are you curious about Octopuses? Octopuses are soft bodied, eight-armed sea creatures that live in the ocean. Here are 8 fantastic facts about octopuses! 

This video is for Kids who LOVE animals!  
Have you ever met an octopus? In this video, you’ll learn about these amazing, intelligent animals. They have very unusual bodies. They’re soft and squishy, because they have no skeleton! And they have 8 arms covered with powerful suckers.  The most amazing thing about octopuses is their big brains that allow them to learn, use tools, and solve puzzles. This makes them very different from other molluscs like clams, mussels, and scallops.

videos.title: Solar Eclipse for Kids || Kids Astronomy || Science for Kids
videos.description:
Do you know what a Solar Eclipse is? Today your monster friend Kromp learns all about Solar Eclipses from the Sun and the Moon. Learn about outer space with your puppet friends! 

Don't forget to SUBSCRIBE for more SMART + FUN videos!
↪ http://bit.ly/SocraticaKids

❤❤❤❤❤

Lunar Eclipse  http://bit.ly/LunarEclipseForKids
Solar Eclipse  http://bit.ly/Astronomy_Kids
Is This a Planet  http://bit.ly/Planet_Game
Mercury for Kids  http://bit.ly/Planet_Mercury
Stars & Constellations  http://bit.ly/StarsForKids

Be sure to SUBSCRIBE so you don’t miss our next episode!
↪ http://bit.ly/SocraticaKids

❤❤❤❤❤

A Total Solar Eclipse can happen during a New Moon. The Moon comes between the Sun and the Earth, and casts a shadow on the Earth.  If you’re standing in the Moon’s shadow, you’ll see the Moon completely block out the Sun. If you’re outside the Moon’s shadow, you’ll see a partial eclipse. 

The stages of a Total Solar Eclipse are
1 - Partial Eclipse
2 - Baily’s Beads
3 - Diamond Ring
4 - Totality

During Totality, you’ll get to see the Sun’s Corona.  That’s the Sun’s outer atmosphere. It’s always there, but the Sun is so bright we can’t see it. We only get the chance to see it during a Total Solar Eclipse. 

★★★VERY IMPORTANT SAFETY NOTE★★★
If you have a chance to watch a Total Solar Eclipse, you MUST wear Eclipse Glasses or you will permanently damage your eyes. 
Many fake eclipse glasses have been sold on Amazon.com
Please read these articles and be safe!  
https://eclipse.aas.org/eye-safety/iso-certification
Here is an approved list of vendors:
https://eclipse.aas.org/resources/solar-filters

videos.title: 9 Herbivore Dinosaurs for Kids – Plant Eating Dinosaurs for Children
videos.description:
Did you know that many dinosaurs were VEGETARIANS?  Another word for animals that only eat plants is HERBIVORE. We can tell which dinosaurs ate plants by looking at fossils of their teeth. Animals that eat plants have very different looking teeth than meat-eaters.  Many plant-eating dinosaurs also had bird-like heads, with a beak.  Here are 9 dinosaurs who loved to eat veggies!  

If your kids loved Jurassic Park and Jurassic World, here’s a great video for them to learn about REAL dinosaurs! We feature 9 dinosaurs from the Jurassic Period and Cretaceous Period, compare their sizes, and show their unusual features. 

Here you can skip to each dinosaur: 
0:20   Triceratops - had 3 horns on its face
1:20    Stegosaurus - had plates sticking up on its back
2:25    Brontosaurus - had a long neck and a long tail
3:29    Therizinosaurus - had the longest claws of any animal
4:46    Ankylosaurus - had a tail like a club
5:48    Parasaurolophus - had a crest like a pipe on its head
6:50    Dracorex - looked like a fairy-tale dragon
8:04    Iguanodon - one of the inspirations for Godzilla
9:02    Stegoceras - had a very thick skull

Which Dinosaur did you like best?

videos.title: Halloween Science Experiments for Kids || Spooky Floating Ghosts || Science for Kids
videos.description:
Time to do Halloween Science Experiments for Kids! Are you ready for some Spooky Science fun?  We're getting ready for Halloween and making Floating Ghosts! You can make some, too! 

In this video, Charlie shows you how to make tissue paper ghosts that can fly when you wave a balloon over them!  How does it work?

It's because of STATIC ELECTRICITY.  If you rub a balloon on your hair, you build up negative charges (electrons) on the balloon.  The tissue paper has positive charges that are attracted to the negative charges on the balloon!  It's Spooky Science!  

We also do an experiment. Remember, an experiment is when you test a hypothesis.  Charlie makes a hypothesis that lighter materials like tissue paper will fly easier than heavier ones like regular paper.  Watch as we test this hypothesis!  You can do your own experiment at home by cutting out ghosts of different materials and seeing which ones work best.  Remember to make a hypothesis and then test it!

videos.title: Glowing Jello || Halloween Science Experiments for Kids || Tonic Water Jello
videos.description:
Here’s a fun treat you can make for Halloween - GLOWING JELLO!  Are you ready to have some Spooky Science Fun?  Let’s make this weird glow in the dark jello together!

Our puppet friend Charlie explains that this isn’t actually “glow-in-the-dark” jello, because it doesn’t glow on its own.  First, you shine a black light on it (UV or ultraviolet) - then the jello fluoresces out a different color light that we can see.  

CAUTION:  DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY AT THE BLACK LIGHT!
UV LIGHT DAMAGES YOUR EYES. 

Here’s what you need to make glowing jello at home:
1 package of Jello (any brand will do) - green works better than orange or red
1 cup boiling water
1 cup tonic water
A bowl
A spoon
A refrigerator

Do you know which of these ingredients makes the jello glow?  It’s the TONIC WATER.  Tonic water contains a special ingredient called Quinine. Quinine is fluorescent.  When you shine a black light at it, it absorbs the UV light and fluoresces out a blue light. 

We made our glowing jello in a jar. What shape would you like to make? Tell us in the comments! 

❤❤❤❤❤

videos.title: DIY SpoOky Halloween Sound Maker || Halloween Science Experiments for Kids || Chicken noises
videos.description:
Let’s Have SpoOky Science Fun for Halloween! Today we’ll make a SPoOky Sound Maker!   It sounds like a creaky door, or someone walking up some creaky stairs! You can DIY by following along! It's a great activity for kids Halloween parties!

Our puppet friend Charlie explains how the spooky sound maker works. It’s AMPLIFICATION!

When you rub the string, it vibrates. That makes a sound, but the vibrations are too small for us to hear them. But when you tie the string to the cup, the cup AMPLIFIES the sound. Now the vibrations are big enough to hear them!

(here’s a little secret - you can also use this sound maker to make CHICKEN noises! Charlie shows you how at the end of the video)

Here’s what you need to make the spooky sound maker at home:
1 plastic cup
1 piece of string or yarn - a couple of feet long is good
A paperclip
A damp sponge or damp paper towel
Something pointy like a sharp pencil

What would you like Charlie to make next? Tell us in the comments! 

❤❤❤❤❤

videos.title: 12 Baby Animals for Kids || Cute Animals for Kids || Learn Animal Names
videos.description:
What do you call baby animals? You know a baby dog is called a puppy...but what about a baby horse? Did you know that baby animals often have a different name than grownup animals?  Today, we’ll meet 12 cute animals and learn what they’re called as babies.  We’ll learn about the animals, too!  Get ready to meet some adorable baby animals...

Hatchling  (Baby Alligator)
Cub  (Baby Bear)
Calf  (Baby Cow or Bull)
Fawn (Baby Deer)
Fry, Fingerling  (Baby Fish)
Kit  (Baby Fox)
Tadpole  (Baby Frogs and Toads)
Foal, colt, filly (Baby Horse)
Newborn, Infant, Toddler  (Baby Human)
Joey  (Baby Kangaroo)
Duckling  (Baby Duck)
Owlet  (Baby Owl)

Many thanks to Maddie Moate for including our video in her YouTubeKids Guest Picks playlist!  It's all about New Ideas and Discoveries! See the rest of the playlist here:

videos.title: Sight Words - Grade 1 - How to Read - Dolch sightwords - 1st Grade
videos.description:
Do your kids know all the 1st Grade sightwords? When you learn to read, you need to recognize some words on sight.  These are called "sight words."  In the Dolch system, there are 41 words at the Grade 1 level that beginning readers need to learn. 

This video has all 41 Grade 1 Dolch Sight Words, with each word spelled and pronounced, and used in a sentence. The pictures will help beginning readers remember each word.  Following along with Dolch Sight Words Sentences is a good way to help readers be more confident. 

It's also a great idea to learn sight words if you are new to English (ESL)!

videos.title: What is a Lunar Eclipse? Astronomy for Kids | Kids Science
videos.description:
Do you know what a Lunar Eclipse is?  It's when the Earth's shadow falls on the Moon.  But how does it happen? When does it happen? Why does it happen? 
Join our puppet friend Leonard - he'll talk to the Moon and the Sun and make them explain just what is really going on here. 

The beginning of the video is an explanation of a lunar eclipse for kids. You can skip ahead to see what a lunar eclipse looks like at 6:39. 

There's a Lunar Eclipse coming up on July 16, 2019!  Make sure to share this video with all your friends so they'll know what's going on, too!

videos.title: How the Heart Works for Kids |  Valentine's Day Biology | Anatomy for Kids
videos.description:
Do you know how your heart works? We think about it a lot on Valentine's Day, but does it really look like the candy hearts we eat? Today on Socratica Kids, Rita Fox explains how the Heart works with the help of her friend Scully. Scully used to have a heart, and he misses him very much. Rita and Scully talk all about how important the heart is for helping you stay healthy and active. 

❤ FUN activity ❤ - draw a valentine-shaped heart, and then draw a real heart shaped heart.  How are they similar? How are they different?  Make real heart-shaped valentines this year! 

Would you like to learn about your SKULL?  Join Rita and Scully for another fun anatomy video for kids!
http://bit.ly/Skulls4Kids

videos.title: Big Cats for Kids - Animals for Kids - Lion, Tiger, Leopard, Jaguar and more
videos.description:
In the wild, there are big cats. Huge cats! Cats that are carnivores, meaning they hunt and eat meat. Some of these cats have powerful roars. Some of these giant cats can purr,  just like a housecat! Some live together, while others prefer to live on their own. Here are the world’s biggest cats and some ways we can tell them apart! 

Do you have a cat at home? Does your cat pretend it's a lion or a tiger? Tell us about it in the comments! We love cat stories.

videos.title: EASTER - Bunnies for Kids - Rabbits and Hares - Animals for Kids - Rabbit Facts
videos.description:
Want to know more about Easter Bunnies?
Springtime is BUNNY SEASON!  We call both rabbits and hares bunnies. Can you tell the difference? We'll show you how to tell them apart, and you'll learn lots about these cute cuddly critters. 

There are more than a dozen kinds of wild rabbits, but did you know there are over 200 different breeds of domesticated (tame) bunnies? That's where you'll see a wide variety of sizes and colors.  

Make sure you watch to the end of the video for a BUNNY PARADE where you can see many of the different kinds of rabbits people keep as pets, as well as some of the different kinds of wild bunnies!

videos.title: What are Computers for Kids | Intro to Computers | Programming for Kids
videos.description:
We use computers every day! But what ARE computers and how do they work? Puppet Topher meets his friend Ulka, a computer programmer, who explains to kids how computers work.  This is a basic Intro to Computers and Programming for Kids - if you like this video, let us know and we'll make more videos on this topic! 

In this video, you'll learn about the difference between Hardware and Software, and how to write very good computer programs by giving careful instructions.  Topher writes his first computer program - How to make a Peanut Butter Sandwich.  It's not quite as easy as he thinks it will be! 

Do you use computers? Are you interested in learning how to program?  Tell us about it in the comments!

videos.title: Owls for Kids 🦉 Animals for Kids | Educational Videos for Kids
videos.description:
Owls are mysterious animals. Have you seen one up close? If so, you're lucky!  Most owls hide in plain sight, because they blend in with their surroundings. In this video, we'll learn all about these beautiful birds! We'll talk about the difference between Barn Owls and True Owls.  We'll also learn what owls eat, where they live, and about their remarkable vision and hearing. 

In this video, we mention that a group of owls is called a “parliament.”  If you’d like to learn more names for groups of animals, try this video: http://bit.ly/GroupsOfAnimals

Did you spot our mascot Bertie?  Let us know in the comments where you saw him! 

Looking for a hands-on activity?  You can dissect an owl pellet to find out what the owl has been eating!
Owl Pellet Kit (2) with Tweezers, pointing stick and 8 page booklet

videos.title: Animal Parents | Animals for Kids | Wild Animal Families
videos.description:
Do you know how Animal Parents raise their little ones? Are they anything like our families?  Today we’ll learn about Elephant Parents, Kangaroo Parents, Penguin Parents, Mom and Dad Ducks, and more! Most wild animals look very different from us. But all of these animals have a mother and a father, just like us. 

It might not surprise you that in a lot of animal families, it’s mostly the mom who takes care of her babies. But you’ll also learn about some special animal parents who leave most of the care up to the dad! Do you know which animal dads do most of the work? Watch and find out!

❤❤❤❤❤
Super fun challenge: try to count all the PENGUINS in this video. Write your answer in the comments! 

Here you can jump to each kind of animal parent:

00:15  Elephant
02:21  Orangutan
04:21  Duck

11:13  Seahorse

videos.title: Australian Animals | Animals for Kids | Weird Wild Animals
videos.description:
Do you know what kinds of animals live in Australia? They’re pretty different from the animals in the rest of the world. Kangaroos, Koalas, Wallabies, Wombats, Quokkas, Tasmanian Devils...these are MARSUPIALS. That’s a special kind of mammal that is born very small and underdeveloped. They crawl into their mother’s pouch and finish growing to full size there! 
Then there are even odder mammals called monotremes. These mammals actually LAY EGGS. There are two kinds of monotremes that live in Australia: the duck-billed platypus, and the echidna (also known as the spiny anteater). 
Finally, there are some very large flightless birds in Australia: the emu and the cassowary.  They’re HUGE!
In this video, you’ll learn more about each of these interesting animals like what they eat and how they have families. 

Here you can jump to each kind of Australian animal:
0:16  Koala
1:08  Dingo
2:02  Kangaroo
3:07  Tasmanian Devil
4:07  Wombat
5:17  Wallaby
6:21  Quokka
7:23  Duck-Billed Platypus
8:44  Emu
10:00  Cassowary
11:20  Echidna

videos.title: Planet Mercury | Astronomy for Kids | Solar System Planets
videos.description:
Did you know MERCURY is the Number One planet in our Solar System? Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun. And the Fastest. And the Smallest!  
In this video, your puppet friend Leonard meets Mercury and finds out what life would be like on Planet #1.  
Turns out, Mercury is a lot like a moon. But it’s not a moon - it’s a planet!  Still, just to be sure, they play a game: Mercury, or the Moon?  Play along and see!

videos.title: Why you need SUNSCREEN  ||  SPF for Kids
videos.description:
Do you have to force your kids to put on sunscreen? Maybe they just don't understand how important it is! Today our puppet friend Rita Fox explains How Sunscreen works to kids. We'll learn what SPF means and how you can figure out how long you can stay in the sun without getting burned. 
We'll talk about the natural protection the Ozone layer gives the Earth, and how you can avoid UV Rays by staying in the shade and applying sunscreen. 
We'll even learn what "Broad Spectrum" sunscreen means, and how there are now sunscreens that are "Reef Safe!" 

☀️☀️☀️☀️☀️☀️☀️☀️

videos.title: 8 Halloween Animals | Animals for Kids | Wild Animals
videos.description:
Which animals do you think of at Halloween?  There are certain animals that are associated with Halloween for their spooky appeal. But are they actually scary?  A common theme these animals share is they are NOCTURNAL, meaning they are active during the night. They are also PREDATORS, which means they hunt for food. Here are eight animals that creep right in with Halloween!

Here you can jump to each kind of spooky Halloween animal:

0:20  Owls
1:04  Rats
1:53  Bats
3:05  Cats
4:05  Spiders
5:21  Ravens
6:08  Wolves
7:01  Toads

videos.title: The Skull for Kids  - Halloween & Dia de Los Muertos - Anatomy for Kids
videos.description:
Do you know why you have a skull?  Today on Socratica Kids, Rita Fox explains how important your skull is with the help of her friend Scully the Skeleton. Scully knows a lot about all the parts of the skull - there are 22 bones in the skull. 8 of them make up the Cranium, which protects your brain. The other 14 bones are Facial Bones. Do you know what is the one bone in your skull you can move? Scully knows! Watch and find out! 

Fun activity idea - draw your own Dia de los Muertos skulls! 

Are you looking for more SMART + FUN videos for Halloween?
We have a playlist of Halloween videos for you to try:
http://bit.ly/Halloween_Videos

videos.title: Horses for Kids | Animals for Kids | Pony, Mule, Donkey
videos.description:
Do you love HORSES? What about Ponies? Did you know that a pony is a kind of a horse? And what’s the difference between a mule and a donkey? We’ll learn all about these beautiful animals - what they eat, do they really sleep standing up...and how we measure them using a really weird unit: HANDS. 

We'll also learn about all the different names we use to describe a horse family: A mother horse (dam), a father horse (sire), a baby horse (foal), whether it's a boy (colt) or a girl (filly). A grown-up female horse is a mare, while a grown-up male horse is a stallion.

How many different kinds of horses do you know? We have a PARADE of HORSES for you - see how many you can name! 

Here's a special challenge for you if you love COUNTING. How many horses are there in this video? Post your answer in the comments!

videos.title: Turkeys for Kids | Wild Turkeys | Animals for Kids | Thanksgiving bird
videos.description:
𝙎𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙛𝙞𝙩: 
💙  https://socratica.kindful.com

🦃 Turkeys are GIANT birds that live in North America. Did you know that Benjamin Franklin wanted the Turkey to be the National Bird of the United States? It really is an impressive bird - wild turkeys get up to around 30 pounds. That’s probably why they are associated with family feasts in America. But how much do you know about the turkey?
For instance, did you know that turkeys can fly?  Wild Turkeys, that is. Domesticated turkeys have gotten too big to fly around. But they can still run very fast! 
And what are all those complicated structures on a turkey’s head? Wattle, carbuncle, snood, beard? Watch our video and find out!

Happy Thanksgiving to all the Socratica Kids out there! 
🍗 Gobble Gobble! 

📆 Playlist of Special Days for Kids: http://bit.ly/Holidays4Kids
Learn about the history and meanings of holidays from cultures around the world! 


❤❤❤❤❤
Turkeys live in a variety of environments. They really like living in part grassland, part forest. If you're curious and want to learn more about these habitats, we have two videos:
🌽 Temperate Grassland: https://youtu.be/llkPgycSkNg
🍁 Temperate Forest: https://youtu.be/WSEa2RDa7P8

videos.title: Polar Bears for Kids | Wild Animals | Arctic Animals
videos.description:
These giant white bears are POLAR BEARS!  They live in the Arctic where it is very, very cold. They have a nice thick layer of blubber that helps keep them warm. They also have two coats! A thick, short, undercoat, and a longer layer of guard hairs.  Did you know that a Polar Bear’s coat isn’t really white? It’s translucent, and it looks white to us because it is reflecting light. 

Come learn more about Polar Bears with us! 
And if you’re curious about other Arctic Animals, we have a video for you:
http://bit.ly/ArcticOceanAnimals

videos.title: Reindeer for Kids | Caribou | Wild Animals | Arctic Animals
videos.description:
Reindeer are a species of deer that live way up close to the North Pole, where it’s very cold. 
Arctic Tundra: https://youtu.be/UzKKrqRtcow
Reindeer actually go by two different names. In North America, wild reindeer are called CARIBOU. In Northern Europe and Asia, they are called REINDEER. But when caribou become domesticated in North America, that is, kept in herds by people, we call them reindeer again.
Some scientists think the reindeer was one of the first domesticated animals - way back around 2000 years ago. Some people who live in the Arctic still depend on reindeer for meat, milk, clothing, and even transportation. You’ve heard of Santa’s sleigh, right? That’s the idea.

In this video, you'll learn all about Reindeer and how they are specially adapted to live in the cold. We'll show you how you can tell the difference between reindeer and other deer - it's all about the antlers! 

Many people associate reindeer with Christmas.  Legend tells of a very kind man named Santa Claus who has a magical sleigh, pulled by a team of flying reindeer. Do you know all the names of Santa's reindeer? We'll learn about those, too!

Come learn more about Reindeer with us! 

And if you’re curious about other Arctic Animals, we have a video for you:
http://bit.ly/ArcticOceanAnimals

videos.title: Pigs for Kids | Year of the Pig 2019 | Wild Animals
videos.description:
Happy 2019, the Year of the Pig!  We grow up with pigs in Nursery Rhymes (this little piggy went to the market) and storybooks (Charlotte’s Web, The Three Little Pigs) - but how much do you really know about these clever animals?  For instance, did you know that pigs dream like us?  And they can get a sunburn like us? 

Pigs have been a part of human culture for thousands of years. Everywhere people live, there are pigs! There are over a billion domestic pigs living all over the world. But there are also wild pigs still running around the countryside. Do you know the differences between wild pigs and domesticated pigs? Learn all this and more with our SMART + FUN video for kids! 

We mentioned the Three Little Pigs. Have you heard this story? Here's our version! 
http://bit.ly/3_Little_Pigs

2019 is the Year of the Pig, according to the Chinese Zodiac. 
If you want to learn more about the Chinese New Year, here's our special video: http://bit.ly/ChineseNewYear4Kids

We also made a video all about the animals that live in China. Go see!
http://bit.ly/Chinese_Animals

videos.title: Groundhogs for Kids | Groundhog Day | Wild Animals
videos.description:
Do you believe the Groundhog can predict when Spring will arrive?  Legend says that when a groundhog wakes up from hibernation and peeks out of its burrow, if it sees its shadow it gets scared and hides back underground. That means 6 more weeks of winter!  
We celebrate this legend every February 2nd on Groundhog Day.  But how much do you know about these cute little rodents? Did you know that they make tunnels called Burrows that get up to 20 meters long? And did you know that each burrow is for something special? They have a burrow to sleep, a burrow to hibernate, a burrow to have baby groundhogs, and even a bathroom burrow!

There’s also a fun tongue twister associated with the groundhog. The groundhog is also known as the Woodchuck (it has a lot of other nicknames, too).  The famous tongue-twister is:

How much wood would a woodchuck chuck
If a woodchuck could chuck wood? 
A woodchuck would chuck all the wood he could
If a woodchuck could chuck wood. 

Let’s have a contest! How fast can you say it?

Do you celebrate Groundhog Day where you live?
Here's our playlist of Special Days for Kids. 
Learn about the history and meanings of holidays from cultures around the world! 
http://bit.ly/Holidays4Kids

videos.description:
𝙎𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙛𝙞𝙩:

https://youtu.be/x_rxe4B67ns
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨:

https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/czklr

https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/kvdqy

Happy Lunar New Year! 2025 is the Year of the SNAKE! 2024 wass the Year of the Dragon; 2023 was the Year of the Rabbit; 2022 was the year of the TIGER; 2021 was -the Year of the Ox; 2020 was the Year of the Rat; and 2019 was the year of the Pig. We often call it Chinese New Year, but the Lunar New Year is celebrated in many Asian countries. It's based on the phases of the moon! The first day of the Lunar New Year begins on the New Moon that appears between January 21st and February 20th. 

Our friend the Moon is here to explain this beautiful and exciting holiday. We should say holidays, because the Lunar New Year celebration lasts for 15 days!  It's the longest national holidays. Many people travel from all over to visit with their families, and kids even get a whole month off from school!

The Lunar New Year is associated with the Chinese Zodiac. There is a small cycle of 12 years, each year denoted by a special animal sign. These are the Rat, Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, Horse, Sheep (or Goat), Monkey, Rooster, Dog, and Pig. Then the cycle begins again! 

In this video, we'll learn about the traditional activities that take place on each of the 15 days of the Lunar New Year celebrations, including eating special foods, setting off fireworks, receiving red envelopes with money inside, and lighting special red lanterns. 

We have a special video about the 12 Chinese Zodiac Animals! Which animal are you?

videos.title: Pi for Kids | What is Pi | Pi Day March 14th | 22/7
videos.description:
What is that funny looking symbol? It’s the Greek Letter Pi. It looks like a crooked little table! But it is important in math and physics and LIFE. Did you know that pi will help you figure out how much pizza you have? How big is your cookie? You can use pi to understand anything that is shaped like a circle. 
Pi is an interesting number. It never ends! It starts out 
3.141 5926 5358 9793 2384… but it just keeps going, and going, and going…Most of the time we shorten pi to a few digits. In this video we use 3.14, but you can use more digits if you like.  In fact, some people make it a game to memorize as many digits of pi as they can. 

In this video, our puppet friend Charlie celebrates Pi Day by learning about the definition of pi:
Pi is the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter.  This also means that if you know the circumference of a circle, you can find its diameter. Or if you know its diameter, you can find the circumference!

Pi is also in the equation for the Area of a circle.  The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared. (The radius is one half of the circle’s diameter).  This is the formula that Charlie is REALLY excited about, because it lets him figure out what is a better deal: one 18-inch pizza or two 12-inch pizzas. Do you know?  Let’s find out, using Pi!

Do you celebrate Pi Day on March 14th (3-14)? 
There's also Pi Approximation Day, July 22nd (22/7).  Another chance to celebrate!
 How many digits of Pi do you know by heart? Tell us about it in the comments!

videos.title: Bad Bugs - Insect Pests for Kids
videos.description:
We love learning about insects, but some bugs are really just PESTS!  Oh sure, they’re interesting, with 6 legs, 3 body parts, and an exoskeleton. Some of them come in vibrant colors or have beautiful wings. But some of them want to bite you or eat your food!  Do you find these bugs pesky?  Learn all about these 11 insects - where they live, what they eat, and whether or not they want to eat you!

Learn all about bad bugs and insect pests in our SMART + FUN video!
Here you can skip to each insect:
0:13  Flea - they make your pets itchy
1:22  House Fly - they eat your food
3:08  Beetle - they eat crops
3:56  Cockroach - they invade your house
5:00  Termite - they eat your house
6:13  Locust - a swarm of hungry grasshoppers
7:15  Fruit Fly - they eat your fruit
8:21  Louse - they want to live in your hair
9:15  Stink Bug - they’re stinky!
10:31  Bedbug - they’ll drink your blood

videos.title: Earth Day for Kids |  5 Easy Ways Kids can Help
videos.description:
𝙎𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙛𝙞𝙩: https://socratica.kindful.com
April 22nd is Earth Day! Mother Earth is here to tell our froggy friend Leonard all about this special holiday. Leonard wonders what can he do? After all, he’s just a little frog. Leonard learns about 5 easy things he can do to help take care of Mother Earth. You can do these 5 things too!!
Earth Day is a holiday celebrated all around the globe by over a BILLION people!  Will you join in this year? Watch our Earth Day for Kids video to learn how you can celebrate our beautiful Earth on April 22nd and EVERY day! 

This video introduces kids to the history of Earth Day as well as giving them simple, easy ideas on how to be “green.”  Conservation for kids is easy if you start early and just do sensible things! The ideas in this video include: Zero-waste lunch, using a re-usable water bottle, turning off the lights when you’re not using them, turning off the water when you brush your teeth, and unplugging appliances when you’re not using them so they don’t keep using electricity. 

How many of these tips do you do already? Do you have other ideas on how to help Mother Earth? 
𝙎𝙃𝘼𝙍𝙀 this video on Socials to spread the word.

videos.title: Black Holes for Kids | Event Horizon Telescope M87
videos.description:
Do your kids want to understand Black Holes? Now's the perfect time to learn about black holes since the Event Horizon Telescope just got its first picture of M87, the black hole in the galaxy Messier 87. 

Our puppet friends Kromp & Leonard talk about how black holes form from dying stars, and what it means for a black hole to be "invisible."  We can't take a regular photograph of a black hole, because it absorbs light and no light can escape from the Event Horizon.  

So how does the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) work? It's an array of RADIO telescopes networked all around the world, and it's detecting radio waves coming off of the accretion disk, the bright burning disk of dust and gas swirling around M87.  

Take a look at the first picture of M87 from the EHT, and Kromp and Leonard will explain what you are looking at!

videos.title: Arbor Day for Kids | Holiday for Planting Trees
videos.description:
𝙎𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙛𝙞𝙩: https://socratica.kindful.com
What’s Arbor Day? It’s a holiday celebrating TREES.  The name Arbor Day comes from the Latin Word for tree. On Arbor Day, we visit trees, sit under trees, hug trees, and even plant trees. Arbor Day doesn’t always on the same day every year, but it’s usually in the Spring when the ground isn’t frozen anymore. That makes it easier to plant trees!

Arbor Day is celebrated in many places around the world. Do you celebrate Arbor Day where you live? 

In this video hosted by our mascot Bertie the Owlet, we talk about the many reasons to love and celebrate trees!  We learn about the history of Arbor Day, back to its earliest celebrations in Spain, and then how it got a big start in the United States, and finally spreading all over the world. 

We also play a fun “mystery tree” game - can you guess the 3 mystery trees? 

Learn what Arbor Day is all about with us! 

If you love learning about science and nature, subscribe to Socratica Kids!

videos.title: Volcanoes for Kids | How Volcanoes Work | Earth Science
videos.description:
Do you know how Volcanoes Work? What makes Volcanoes Erupt? Mother Earth is here to explain. 
Volcanoes are openings on the Earth’s surface where LAVA escapes. Confused about Lava vs Magma? Lava is another word for molten rock (magma) when it escapes above the Earth’s crust. 

In this video, we’ll learn about the layers of the Earth, and how the core (the very center) is VERY hot and under a lot of pressure. It’s so hot, it heats up the other layers, and some of the rocky layers underground melt into MAGMA. Eventually the pressure builds up, and the magma escapes to the surface as LAVA!  

Have you ever seen a volcano erupting? At the end of our video, you’ll get to see a VOLCANO MONTAGE so be sure to watch to the end for that exciting finish!

videos.title: How do Fireworks Work?  ★  Fireworks for Kids  ★ 4th of July
videos.description:
Do you like fireworks? They’re so exciting! They’re loud, and pretty, and you can feel it in your bones when they go off! But do you know how they work? What makes them different colours? In this video, you’ll learn about the invention of fireworks and how modern fireworks actually work.  There are three main stages to most fireworks: 1) the fuse, 2) the lift charge, and 3) the burst charge. Our friend Puppet Charlie explains what goes into these fireworks and also where the different colours come from. We also learn a big word: pyrotechnician - that means someone who works with fireworks as their job. 

We watch fireworks on New Years, the 4th of July, and for many other holidays around the world! What’s your favourite colour of firework? Tell us in the comments!

videos.title: How to Be a Good Student - Puppets give Kids Advice
videos.description:
What’s the secret to being a good student? It may seem like a mystery, but here at Socratica Kids, we’ll show you how!  Our puppet friends Leonard, Topher, and Rita Fox show you how to do well in school. 

Topher is a good student. He listens to his teacher, Rita Fox, who is there to help the students. Leonard still has a little way to go, but anyone can be a good student. Here are a few simple tips to remember:  Show up on time, eat a good breakfast, listen to your teacher, follow the rules, do your homework, raise your hand, use your inside voice, and...no personal parties!  What’s that last one about? You’ll see!

Do you find school challenging?  We’d love to hear from teachers and students about what they find hard, and what they find fun about school.  YouTube is shutting off comments for kids’ videos, but if you’d like to send us mail, you can reach us here:

videos.title: How to Draw a Circle | Kids Art & Math | STEAM
videos.description:
Anyone can learn to draw! All you need is paper to doodle on, and some pencils or crayons.  Today, Ziggy the Doodlebug teaches you a special technique for drawing a CIRCLE. Can you think of things shaped like a circle? We think of a whole bunch together, like a ball, an orange, a clock...We also learn all the names for the parts of a circle! These words come from MATH and it’s important to know what they mean!

The Center: The middle of the circle.
Radius: The distance from the center of the circle to its outer rim.
Chord: A line segment connecting two points on the circle.
Arc: Connect two points on the circle by drawing along the circle’s edge. 
Diameter: The distance across the circle when you go through the center. The length of a diameter is two times the length of the radius. This cuts the circle in half!
Circumference:  The distance all around the edge of the circle.
Area: How much space the circle takes up. It tells you how much coloring you have to do to fill the whole circle.

videos.title: How Do Trees Grow? - Kids STEM #TeamTrees
videos.description:
Donate at https://teamtrees.org to plant 20M trees by Jan 1, 2020!
How do trees get so tall? Do you know? Trees sprout from seeds, just like flowers, but then they grow MUCH MUCH taller. In this video, we’ll talk about HOW trees do it! They don’t grow bigger all over, like you do. They only grow in very special areas. We’ll learn about a special kind of tissue in trees called MERISTEM. We’ll also play a game - can you guess the tree, if you see its seed? Watch and find out! 

Socratica Kids is proud to be part of #TeamTrees!  #TeamTrees is a collaboration of your favourite YouTubers who are working together to plant 20 MILLION trees by January 1st, 2020.  We’re raising funds with the help of the Arbor Day Foundation, who are known around the world for planting and supporting beautiful trees. 

If you want to join #TeamTrees, visit teamtrees.org.  Be sure to get the help of your grownup.  
The goal is to raise $20 million dollars by 1/1/2020. That comes out to $1 per tree. What a bargain! 
The Arbor Day Foundation is working hard to find where in the world are the best places to plant these 20 million trees - where are they needed and where will they grow well. That way the trees can grow strong and healthy, and can contribute to a healthier planet for all of us! 

We have a related video all about Arbor Day:
http://bit.ly/ArborDay4Kids

videos.title: 15 Dog Breeds | Dogs for Kids
videos.description:
Dogs have been our friends and  companions for a very long time. The dogs we know and love are descended from wolves. Scientists estimated that dogs were domesticated, or made pet-friendly, 15,000 years ago. Wow! That’s longer than humans have raised farm animals, and certainly longer than humans have had pet cats. There are so many different types of dogs. Big dogs, little dogs, fluffy dogs, super playful dogs and more. Here are 15 popular dogs breeds that everyone loves! 

You can jump to each kind of dog here:
Golden Retriever
Pomeranian
Labrador Retriever
Chihuahua
English Bulldog
French Bulldog
Pug
Siberian Husky
Boxer
Dachshund
Beagle
Pit Bull
Shih Tzu
Corgi
German Shepherd

videos.title: Phonics Reading Lesson 1...Mm
videos.description:
Learn to Read in ~10 minutes a Day
𝙎𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙛𝙞𝙩: https://socratica.kindful.com
𝙎𝙞𝙜𝙣 𝙪𝙥 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙘𝙡𝙖𝙨𝙨: https://snu.socratica.org/learn-to-read
We’re here to help kids learn how to read. Our lessons are clear and simple to follow. There are no distractions of music or sound effects. By staying completely focused on learning to read, it just takes about 10 minutes to get through each lesson. 

Each reading lesson builds on the previous one, so it’s important to sign up to our mailing list so you don’t miss any lessons. 
𝙅𝙤𝙞𝙣 𝘾𝙡𝙖𝙨𝙨 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙁𝙧𝙚𝙚: https//snu.socratica.org/learn-to-read

In Lesson 1, we learn the sound m. This is also called a 𝙥𝙝𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙢𝙚.
Rather than focusing on naming the letters of the alphabet, phonics focuses on "sounding out" words based on the sounds each letter represents. Recognizing phonemes and being able to sound out words is an important step that eliminates most of the guesswork that causes struggles for beginning readers.

In this lesson, we also see and pronounce these words:
mat
ram
me
am
man
ham
mad
jam

In the word list, there are words that begin with the m sound, and there are words that end with the m sound. We practice reading and saying these words both slowly and quickly. This way students get practice with 𝙗𝙡𝙚𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙨 together to make words.  
This phonics practice with blending is an essential part of learning how to read. 

𝙒𝘼𝙏𝘾𝙃 𝙉𝙀𝙓𝙏:
𝙇𝙚𝙨𝙨𝙤𝙣 2 (𝙨 𝙨𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙): https://youtu.be/9sYovtqQVHk
𝘼𝙡𝙥𝙝𝙖𝙗𝙚𝙩 𝙇𝙪𝙡𝙡𝙖𝙗𝙮 (soothing): https://youtu.be/5rw0aR5QdM4
𝙋𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙩 𝘼𝙡𝙥𝙝𝙖𝙗𝙚𝙩 (funny): https://youtu.be/Vl5g0G4DdRg
𝙎𝙪𝙗𝙨𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙗𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙎𝙤𝙘𝙧𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙘𝙖 𝙆𝙞𝙙𝙨 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚: http://bit.ly/SocraticaKids

This series of reading lessons was made possible by the Socratica Foundation. The Socratica Foundation is an educational nonprofit with the mission to build the essential, universal knowledge base every student needs to succeed. We provide a solid educational foundation in the three timeless pillars: 
1) Reading and Writing
2) Math
3) Critical Thinking

𝙇𝙚𝙖𝙧𝙣 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚: https://www.socratica.org/

If you believe this content is valuable, we would appreciate your support. Your contributions are much appreciated!

videos.description:

We’re here to help kids learn how to read. Our lessons are clear and simple to follow. There are no distractions of music or sound effects. By staying completely focused on learning to read, it just takes about 10 minutes to get through each lesson. 

Each reading lesson builds on the previous one, so it’s important to sign up to our mailing list so you don’t miss any lessons. 
𝙅𝙤𝙞𝙣 𝘾𝙡𝙖𝙨𝙨 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙁𝙧𝙚𝙚: https//snu.socratica.org/learn-to-read

In Lesson 2, we review the sound m and learn the new sound s. These are also called 𝙥𝙝𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙨.
Rather than focusing on naming the letters of the alphabet, phonics focuses on "sounding out" words based on the sounds each letter represents. Recognizing phonemes and being able to sound out words is an important step that eliminates most of the guesswork that causes struggles for beginning readers.

In this lesson, we also see and pronounce these words:
mat
sat
me
see
man
Sam
mad
sad
gas

In the word list, there are words that begin with the m sound, and there are words that end with the m sound. There are words that begin with the s sound, and words that end with the s sound. There’s also a special word that combines these sounds - the name Sam. We practice reading and saying these words both slowly and quickly. This way students get practice with 𝙗𝙡𝙚𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙨 together to make words.  
This phonics practice with blending is an essential part of learning how to read.

videos.title: Phonics Reading Lesson 9…Nn
videos.description:
Learn to Read in ~10 minutes a Day
𝙎𝙪𝙥𝙥𝙤𝙧𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙣𝙤𝙣𝙥𝙧𝙤𝙛𝙞𝙩: https://socratica.kindful.com
𝙎𝙞𝙜𝙣 𝙪𝙥 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙘𝙡𝙖𝙨𝙨: https://snu.socratica.org/learn-to-read
We’re here to help kids learn how to read. Our lessons are clear and simple to follow. There are no distractions of music or sound effects. By staying completely focused on learning to read, it just takes about 10 minutes to get through each lesson. 

Each reading lesson builds on the previous one, so it’s important to sign up to our mailing list so you don’t miss any lessons. 
𝙅𝙤𝙞𝙣 𝘾𝙡𝙖𝙨𝙨 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙁𝙧𝙚𝙚: https//snu.socratica.org/learn-to-read
𝙎𝙩𝙖𝙧𝙩 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙇𝙚𝙨𝙨𝙤𝙣 1 (𝙢 𝙨𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙):  https://youtu.be/hAqk1NnPU_I

In Lesson 9, We learn a new sound, n. We review the sound m, which sounds similar to n. These are also called 𝙥𝙝𝙤𝙣𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙨.
Rather than focusing on naming the letters of the alphabet, phonics focuses on "sounding out" words based on the sounds each letter represents. Recognizing phonemes and being able to sound out words is an important step that eliminates most of the guesswork that causes struggles for beginning readers.

In this lesson, we also see and pronounce these words:
nap
map
can
man
ham
ran
mat
pan
Sam
fan
me
in

In the word list, we are reviewing some of the words from previous lessons that use both of the m and n sounds. We practice reading and saying these words both slowly and quickly. This way students get practice with 𝙗𝙡𝙚𝙣𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙨𝙤𝙪𝙣𝙙𝙨 together to make words.  
This phonics practice with blending is an essential part of learning how to read.

videos.title: Why do we have Leap Year? February 29th #shorts
videos.description:
Is this a leap year? When do we get a February 29th?
So, as you know, we have 365 days in a year. But did you know that the time it takes for the Earth to go around the sun is actually a little bit longer than that? It's about 365 and a quarter days!

That extra quarter day might not seem like a lot, but over time, it adds up. After four years, those quarter days add up to one extra day. That's why we have Leap Year!

A leap year is a year that has one extra day in it. It happens every four years, and that extra day is added to the month of February. So instead of having 28 days, February has 29 days in a leap year.

Watch more videos about special days here:

videos.title: Happy First Day of Spring #shorts
videos.description:
The first day of spring is a special day when the weather starts to get warmer, the trees and flowers start to grow new leaves and buds, and the days start to get longer. Spring is the season that comes after winter, and it's a time of renewal and new beginnings.

During the first day of spring, which is also called the "spring equinox," the sun is in a special position in the sky that makes the day and night almost equal in length. This happens because the Earth is tilted on its axis, which causes different parts of the planet to get more or less sunlight at different times of the year.

So, the first day of spring is a very exciting day because it means that winter is over and warmer, sunnier days are on the way!

videos.description:

Can you name the 8 Largest Animals on Planet Earth? Not all of the biggest animals live on land. Don't forget to look DEEP in the ocean! And here's another thing to keep in mind: what do we mean when we say BIGGEST? Is it the longest? The tallest? The heaviest?  

In this video, we'll meet the largest land mammal - the African elephant; the largest ocean mammal - the blue whale; the largest reptile - the saltwater crocodile; the largest bird - the ostrich; bonus largest bird that can fly - the wandering albatross; the largest primate - the Eastern gorilla; the largest mollusk (in length) - the Giant Squid; and the largest amphibian - the South China Giant Salamander. Did you know these were the largest of their kind?

Cats are pretty special. Did you know they tamed themselves? They figured out they'd have a good life living on a farm with people and they were right! There was plenty to eat (like mice and rats that tried to eat the grain), and plenty of petting and affection from the people! That happened about 10,000 years ago, and since then people have bred cats to produce all kinds of different kitties. Different coats, different behaviors, etc. We love them all!

videos.description:
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨:

🧩 An activity bundle (includes word search & crossword puzzle): 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/oqjrnq

🐬 Dolphins are MAMMALS like us—not fish! But how do they survive living in the water? We sure couldn't do that. Dolphins have some special adaptations that make them very well suited for ocean life. These include being able to hold their breath for a long time, having a blowhole on top of their heads so they can quickly grab a breath of fresh air when they surface, special flippers that help them swim quickly through the water - they can even do something called ECHOLOCATION that allows them to find their way around and hunt for prey even in dark murky waters.

videos.description:

Under the surface of the ocean live the most gigantic creatures on the planet! The Blue Whale is actually the largest animal to EVER live on Planet Earth—even bigger than the biggest dinosaurs! 
Of course, not all whales are as big as the Blue whale. Some are around our size, like the playful dolphins! And there are many different whales in between. In this video, we'll learn more about the special qualities of these giant mammals. That's right—even though they live in the water, whales are mammals and breathe air, just like us.

videos.title: Butterflies are FANCY Insects 🦋 Metamorphosis 🐛 Pollination 🌻
videos.description:
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨:
🎨 SMART+FUN coloring pages with animal facts: 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/ywzwc
🧩 An activity bundle (includes word search & crossword puzzle): 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/mrxzw

Butterflies are insects, but they must be the FANCIEST insects around! They have the same 3 main body parts as all insects: head, thorax, and abdomen. But they have extraordinary, beautiful, multicolored wings that allow them to flutter around, going from flower to flower 🌻, pollinating and drinking nectar with their long, curved proboscis. 
They also undergo one of the most dramatic changes of any animal: they do metamorphosis, changing from an egg, to a worm-like hungry larva (caterpillar) 🐛 to a hard-shelled chrysalis hanging down from a leaf or branch, and finally emerging as an adult butterfly with those dramatically coloured wings. 🦋

videos.title: BEES don't realize how great they are! 🐝 Pollination, Honey, & Beeswax
videos.description:
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨:
🎨 SMART+FUN coloring pages with animal facts: 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/xyvyb
🧩 An activity bundle (includes word search & crossword puzzle): 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/ygfih

We should really think of a way to thank the bees. They must be the hardest working insects in the world! They do a lot of the hard work needed to pollinate flowers and help plants grow. They also make honey, which is delicious, and beeswax, which they use to make their honeycomb (and we use in candles). 

Like all insects, bees have 3 main body parts as all insects: head, thorax, and abdomen. But bees have some additional special structures you'll learn about in this video including a HONEY STOMACH, POLLEN BASKETS, and a STINGER!

We'll also find out more about how pollination works, how honey is made from nectar, and how bees live their complicated, highly social life back at the beehive. We'll also learn about a few different kinds of bees: honey bee, bumble bee, carpenter bee, and even a blue bee!

🏙️ Cities are busy places, full of lots of people. You may have even noticed some animals in the city, like pigeons and rats! videos.title: 10 Beetles 🐞 Know them Love them
videos.description:
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨
🎨 SMART+FUN coloring pages with animal facts: 
   https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/zvvms
🧩 An activity bundle (includes word search & double puzzle): 
   https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/ndjyk

Did you know there are more kinds of beetles than any other kind of animal? There are more than 350,000 different species of beetles—that we know of so far! They are amazingly specialized for where they live and what they eat. You can tell this because it's their jaw and mouthparts that are so radically different between different species of beetles. 

But you know what they all have in common? Beetles are all insects! That means they share some features with all insects: they have 3 main body parts (head, thorax, and abdomen), they have compound eyes and antennae for sensing things, they have 2 sets of wings, and 6 jointed legs. And instead of a skeleton made of bones inside their body, they have an exoskeleton. 

In this video, we'll meet 10 beetles that are all special in their own way. How many of these beetles do you know already? Do any of them live in your neighborhood?

videos.title: all about REPTILES 🦎🐢 + BONUS downloads activity pages
videos.description:
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨:
🎨 SMART+FUN coloring pages with animal facts: 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/tqcarq
🧩 An activity bundle (includes word search & crossword puzzle): 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/wertm

Reptiles are some of the oldest animals on Earth. If you need help remembering that, just think: Dinosaurs and Pterosaurs were reptiles! The dinosaurs went extinct around 65 million years ago, but we still live with their descendants. Modern reptiles include snakes, lizards, turtle, crocodiles, alligators, geckos, komodo dragons, tortoises...can you think of any others?

In this video, you'll see many different reptiles and you'll learn about what they have in common and what distinguishes them from one another. For instance, reptiles are all "cold-blooded" (the scientific term is ectothermic), which actually means their body temperature is influenced by their surroundings. That's why you see reptiles sunning themselves! 

𝙅𝙪𝙢𝙥 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙙𝙞𝙛𝙛𝙚𝙧𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙖𝙣𝙞𝙢𝙖𝙡𝙨 𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚:

6:50 Turtles vs tortoises
7:13 Alligators vs crocodiles

videos.title: NOCTURNAL animals 🦇 🐺 awake at NIGHT
videos.description:
𝘽𝙊𝙉𝙐𝙎 𝘿𝙤𝙬𝙣𝙡𝙤𝙖𝙙 𝘼𝙘𝙩𝙞𝙫𝙞𝙩𝙮 𝙥𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙨:
🎨 SMART+FUN coloring pages with animal facts: 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/mfoowq
🧩 An activity bundle (includes word search & crossword puzzle): 
https://socraticafoundation.gumroad.com/l/mctgp

WHAT IF:  bedtime was the start of the day instead of the end? This is the reality for many creatures on Earth. That's right, we're talking about nocturnal animals! These are the critters that sleep during the day and come alive at night. From the silent flight of owls to the sneakiest of sneaky foxes, we're taking a peek at the mysterious lives of these nighttime wanderers. It’s time to turn on your flashlight and shed some light on these nighttime creatures. 
When the sun sets and we're winding down for the night, nocturnal animals are just getting started. Animals who are active during the night are called NOCTURNAL animals. On the other hand, animals who are active during the day, like humans, are called DIURNAL. But it doesn’t end there…there’s actually a special term for animals who are active during the in-between times of dusk and dawn: CREPUSCULAR animals! That’s a fun word to say. CRE-PUS-CU-LAR.  Crepuscular animals include cats, some owls, and even some species of bats. But today, we’ll be focusing on animals who thrive during the dark hours of the night.

videos.description:

This playlist will focus on Earth Science and natural phenomena, including hurricanes, tsunamis, floods, avalanches, earthquakes, tornadoes, and more!  𝙎𝙐𝘽𝙎𝘾𝙍𝙄𝘽𝙀 so you get to see each new video!

𝙎𝙈𝘼𝙍𝙏+𝙁𝙐𝙉 𝙥𝙤𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙧 - What comes out of a volcano?
🎨 https://shop.socratica.org/products/volcanoes-what-comes-out-of-a-volcano
Perfect for classrooms and home study rooms. You'll look at it and laugh, and then remember what it says. 

Do you know how volcanoes work?
Volcanoes are NOT like other mountains, sitting all quiet and pretty. They have a lot going on inside! It gets so hot, rocks melt (we call this molten rock magma). Pressure builds up, and eventually they ERUPT! 

What comes out of a volcano? When the molten rock is on the outside, now we call it LAVA. But that's not all. There are also a variety of gases (like carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, hydrogen sulfide) and ash (very fine particles of rocks, minerals, and glass). 

In this video, you'll see many different volcanoes and learn about how they work. Where on Earth are they found? What do we do to keep an eye on them? Whose job is that, anyway? (Volcanologists)

🎨 https://shop.socratica.org/products/hurricane-galaxy
Perfect for classrooms and home study rooms. You'll look at it and laugh, and then remember what it says. 

Hurricanes are massive storms that form over warm ocean waters. Depending on where you live, you might call them typhoons, or cyclones. Did you know these were three different names for the same kind of giant storm?

When we say giant storm, we mean GIANT storm—hurricanes can be hundreds of miles across. And they look a lot like a spiral galaxy!  How else will you recognize hurricanes? They have an open spot in the middle called the EYE, and surrounding the eye is the EYE WALL.  See also the spiral rain bands.  And the hurricane twists in one direction in the Northern Hemisphere, and clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. 

In this video, you'll see examples of hurricanes and learn about how they work. Where on Earth are they found? What do we do to keep an eye on them? Whose job is that, anyway? (Meteorologists)

videos.description:

🎨 https://shop.socratica.org - check this site regularly
Perfect for classrooms and home study rooms. You'll look at it and laugh, and then remember what it says. 

When you say tsunami, do you know you're speaking Japanese? Tsunami is made up of two Japanese words: tsu (harbor) + nami (wave). So tsunami means "harbor wave" in Japanese. Why were they named this? Because these are the kind of giant waves that destroyed harbors. 

These waves don't play nice on the beach for us to splash in. Tsunami waves stretch up way up tall like a giant wall made of water, rushing onto the shore and mowing down everything in their path. 

In this video, we'll learn about the special ways tsunamis are different from ordinary waves. Where do they come from? How fast do they move? Where on Earth are they most common? What can we do to prepare for them?

videos.description:
𝙉𝙀𝙒 𝙉𝘼𝙏𝙐𝙍𝘼𝙇 𝙒𝙊𝙉𝘿𝙀𝙍𝙎 𝙨𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 🌎😎 𝙎𝙐𝘽𝙎𝘾𝙍𝙄𝘽𝙀! http://bit.ly/SocraticaKids

🎨 https://shop.socratica.org - check this site regularly
Perfect for classrooms and home study rooms. You'll look at our poster and laugh, and then remember what it says. 

Whirlpools are something we can experience in our own homes (on a small scale): you can watch water draining out of your sink or your bathtup or even the toilet! But whirlpools are also a natural phenomenon. They usually happen when two different currents, going in different directions, meet in a body of water. These can happen in the ocean, in a river, or even a lake. 

We're used to stories and myths about GIANT whirlpools sucking down ships. But actually, in nature, whirlpools rarely pull in boats. If you know what to look for, you can avoid them! Also some whirlpools are pretty small. But some are very large, and are even tourist attractions!

videos.description:
𝙉𝙀𝙒 𝙉𝘼𝙏𝙐𝙍𝘼𝙇 𝙒𝙊𝙉𝘿𝙀𝙍𝙎 𝙨𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙚𝙨 🌎😎 𝙎𝙐𝘽𝙎𝘾𝙍𝙄𝘽𝙀! http://bit.ly/SocraticaKids
